Graphical abstract Efficient conversion of methane to higher hydrocarbons via oxidative coupling of methane “OCM” is one of the dream reactions in heterogeneous catalysis. Promising yields of C2 hydrocarbons were reported for nanostructured catalysts based on Mn/Na/W-SiO2. However, the exact role of the nanostructure could not be studied so far due to collapse of the pore structure of the SiO2 support at typical OCM temperatures. We investigate porous SiC as an alternative catalyst support for OCM catalysis. Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts with different pore size were synthesized via impregnation, calcined under different atmospheres and then studied in OCM. The calcination critically impacts the pore structure and surface area of the obtained catalysts. Calcination in nitrogen preserves the support’s structure significantly better than calcination in air. However, the nitrogen-calcined catalysts show a strong loss of porosity during OCM testing. The loss of porosity is caused by the presence of Na, which induces a melting of the surface layer that typically protects SiC against bulk oxidation. OCM tests suggest that the activity and C2 yield of Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts depend critically on the supports stability, i.e. the surface area retained under reaction conditions. Keywords Oxidative methane coupling OCM Silicon carbide Porosity Sodium Surface area 1 Introduction Natural gas is widely utilized as a feedstock for the production of energy and chemicals, but it is largely located in the remote area. Natural gas comprises up to 90% of methane. It is promising to convert methane into either transportation fuels or high value-added chemicals such as ethylene [1,2]. Keller and Bhasin reported in pioneering work that methane conversion to higher hydrocarbons can be achieved via Oxidative Coupling of Methane “OCM” [3]. The OCM typically proceeds at temperatures of about 700°C to 900°C. It comprises coupled surface and gas-phase reactions that convert methane into C2 products (ethane and ethylene) as well as COx. The main goal is to achieve sufficient CH4 conversion and high C2 selectivity simultaneously [4,5]. Many different catalysts have been tested in OCM in the past 30 years. However, C2 yields above 25–30% were rarely obtained so far [6]. Systems based on Li/MgO and on Mn/Na/W/SiO2 represent the two most frequently studied catalysts. Li-doped MgO exhibits high initial activity and selectivity [7], but suffers from an intrinsic instability, which prevents its industrial application [8–10]. Silica-supported oxidic Mn/Na/W-phases reported e.g. by Li et al. [11] show better long-term stability and are therefore frequently studied with respect to active sites, reaction mechanism [12–15] and process engineering [16]. Porous support materials offer potential advantages such as high surface area, facile mass transport and homogeneous dispersion of active sites [17]. Yildiz et al. [18] reported an improved OCM performance of Mn/Na/W/SiO2 catalysts when ordered mesoporous silica (SBA-15) was used as the support material. Both, a better dispersion of Mn-Na2WO4 precursors in the support pore system and the high surface area of SBA-15 might have contributed to this improvement. However, the mesostructure of SBA-15 collapsed during thermal treatments and under OCM reaction conditions. Thus, the contribution of porosity to the catalytic processes remained unknown. Silicon carbide (SiC) is usually described as a material with good stability at high temperature, chemical inertness and high mechanical strength, which are all required for a superior heterogeneous catalyst support [19]. SiC possesses a three dimensional structure of Si and C atoms, where each atom is surrounded tetrahedrally by four of the other kind. It exists in more than 250 polymorphs and some of them are variations of the same chemical compound that are identical in two dimensions and differ in the third [20]. Two major kinds of silicon carbide are α-SiC and β modification (β-SiC or 3C-SiC), having hexagonal and zinc blende crystal structure, respectively. Hoffmann et al. [21] reported that mesoporous β-SiC prepared via hard templating and corresponding Ni/SiC catalyst exhibited higher conversion and stability in dry reforming of methane at 800°C than conventional SiO2 as a support. Leroi et. al [22] reported that β-SiC as support for Ni showed comparable activity to Ni/γ-Al2O3 as well as excellent stability in the partial oxidation of methane at 900°C. Few papers mentioned SiC as a support for OCM reaction. Yildiz et al. [23] carried out support variation for MnxOy-Na2WO4 catalysts for OCM, where SiC supported catalysts showed lower CH4 conversion and similar C2 selectivity at 750°C compared to SiO2 support. Serres et al. [24] reported SiC-supported Na2WO4-Mn2O3 catalysts and their application in OCM. C2 yields of about 6% at 10% methane conversion level were reached, despite the unusual high loading of 19.5 and 41.0wt% of tungsten. Unfortunately, these catalysts provided the surface area below 1m2/g. Moreover, neither the stability and transformation of the support during OCM nor the role of porosity were investigated in detail. In order to assess the role of porosity and surface area in OCM catalysis on silicon carbide supported Mn/Na/W phases, we prepared OCM catalysts via impregnation of SiC supports of different pore structures. Catalysts were calcined in different atmospheres and tested in OCM reaction. Complementary physico-chemical characterization and thermogravimetric analysis provided insights into the factors that control the activity and stability of differently prepared Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts under reaction conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of SiC supported Mn/Na/W catalysts Commercial porous SiC granules with different pore sizes were obtained from SICAT and named “SiC 27” and “SiC 56”, where the number indicates the most frequent pore size measured in nm. The granules were grounded and sieved into size fraction from 224 to 500μm. Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts containing 2wt% Mn and 5wt% Na2WO4 on SiC were synthesized via a new two-step wet impregnation in a self-made apparatus. It is composed of a syringe pump and a rotary evaporator with controlled vacuum. Typically, 1.0g of SiC support was put into a 100mL flask and preheated for 15min in a water bath to 72°C with rotation at 58rpm. 91.0mg Mn(NO3)2·4H2O (Aldrich, ≥97.0%) was dissolved in 10mL milli-Q H2O. The Mn(NO3)2 solution was continuously dosed to the SiC in the rotary evaporator (80mbar) via syringe pump at a rate of 1.7mL/h. The material was then dried in air at 120°C overnight. After that, the obtained material was impregnated with 10mL aqueous solution of 56.0mg Na2WO4·2H2O (Aldrich, ≥99.0%) and dried in a similar fashion. Finally, the as-coated SiC samples were heated up to 250°C with 10Kmin−1 in air or nitrogen for 1h. Thereafter, they were further heated to 800°C with 10Kmin−1 in air or nitrogen and maintained at the same temperature for 8h. Uncoated SiC was thermally treated in the same way for comparison. Moreover, a Mn/Na/W/SiO2 catalyst was synthesized in a similar way using silica gel (Aldrich, Davisil, Grade 634) as support. 2.2 Characterization SEM images of uncoated supports and catalysts were recorded on a JEOL 7401F instrument at 10kV acceleration voltage and 8mm working distance. XRD was measured using a Bruker D8 advance powder diffractometer in Bragg-Brentano geometry (CuKα source, λ=0.15405nm), variable divergence slit and a position sensitive LynxEye detector. For physisorption test the Quantachrome Autosorb-1 was used. The samples were treated at 150°C overnight before the measurement at 77K. BET method for relative pressure p/p0 from 0.05-0.30 was used to determine specific surface area ABET. The pore size distribution was determined by NLDFT equilibrium model of silica with cylindrical pore from the adsorption and desorption branch of the N2 isotherm. The bulk composition of the catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). ICP-OES was performed using a 715-ES-ICP analysis system (Varian). XP spectra were recorded with an Omicron DAR 400 X-ray source with Al Kα excitation. Electrons were detected with an EA 125X Hemispherical Energy Analyzer. TGA was measured on a PerkinElmer STA 8000. For each measurement approximately 20mg of sample was tested in synthetic air or nitrogen (100mLmin−1) from 30°C to 1050°C with ramping rate of 10Kmin−1. 2.3 OCM catalytic test Activity and stability of the catalysts were tested in a reactor system developed at the Leibniz Institute for Catalysis. This system consists of 6 continuous-flow fixed-bed quartz tubular (internal diameter=6mm) reactors located in the same oven and operating in parallel. 50mg catalyst (size fraction 224–500μm) was placed on a quartz wool plug covered with roughly 700mg SiC particles to ensure proper heat transfer. The feed gas was continuously dosed at a composition of CH4:O2:N2 =2:1:4 (methane and synthetic air as oxygen source) with a total gas flow rate of 88.1mLSTP min−1. This flow was equally distributed to the reactors filled with catalysts. They were initially heated in the feed gas to 450°C. Thereafter, the temperature was increased in steps of 25K from 450°C to 800°C. At each temperature the OCM reaction was performed for about one hour. An online gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890) was used for quantifying O2, N2, CO, and CO2 with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and CH4, C2H4, C2H6 with a flame ionization detector (FID). N2 was used as internal standard. After competing OCM tests, the reactors were cooled down to room temperature in the feed gas. With the same feed gas composition, the stability of OCM catalyst was tested at reaction temperature of 600 and 700°C. The CH4 conversion was calculated from the inlet and outlet molar ( n ˙ ) flow according to Eq. (1). The desired reaction products of OCM are C2H4 and C2H6. We report their overall yield as written in Eq. (2). Carbon balance was calculated from carbon input (as CH4) and output (as CH4, CO, CO2, C2H4, C2H6, C3H6 and C3H8) according to Eq. (3). Obtained representative results are shown in Fig. 1 . SiC 27 and SiC 56 in the “as is” state are composed of fine particles with apparent interparticle voids. Type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms with H3 hysteresis loop was determined for these both supports (see SI, Fig. S1). The adsorption is mainly above p/p0 =0.8, indicating a significant contribution of large mesopores arising from SiC interparticle voids. Specific surface areas of SiC 27 and SiC 56 amount to 26.1 and 28.4m2 g−1 respectively (see Table 1 ). As seen in Fig. 1b, pore size distributions calculated via NLDFT equilibrium model feature a broad peak centered around 27nm (SiC 27-as is) or 56nm (SiC 56-as is). XRD analysis (Fig. 1c) shows well-defined reflection which can be attributed to a 3C-SiC phase (JCPDS 29-1129). Heat treatments of the SiC supports at 800°C in either air (SiC 27-calc air, SiC 56-calc air) or N2 (SiC 27-calc N2, SiC 56-calc N2) do not alter their fine-grained morphology significantly (Fig. 1a). The supports also retain their high surface area of about 30m2/g (Table 1) and do not change their pore size distribution (Fig. 1b): the maxima around 27nm (SiC 27) and 56nm (SiC 56) are still observed. Calcination in air and in N2 preserves also the 3C-SiC crystalline phases. Hence, both investigated porous SiC support materials are stable in N2 and in air at typical OCM temperatures. 3.2 Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts before OCM The SiC support SiC 27 and SiC 56 materials were impregnated with Mn and Na2WO4 precursor solutions and calcined in air (SiC xx-Mn/Na/W-calc air) or in N2 flow (SiC xx-Mn/Na/W-calc N2) at 800°C in order to obtain active catalysts. The bulk composition of catalysts was determined by ICP-OES. As shown in Fig. S2, e.g., SiC 27-Mn/Na/W, the amount of Na, W and Mn in the catalysts is 0.63%, 2.52% and 1.81%, respectively. The determined Mn, Na and W values are close to intended values within acceptable experimental error. Fig. 2 displays corresponding (a) SEM, (b) pore size distribution and (c) XRD data. For both catalysts, calcination in air induces particle sintering and loss of the fine-grained morphology (Fig. 2a). Physisorption result indicates a complete loss of mesoporosity (SI, Fig. S3a). The maxima in pore size distribution observed for the uncoated SiC supports disappear completely (Fig. 2b). Moreover, the surface area of the air-calcined catalysts is drastically lower (1.9m2 g−1 for SiC 27-Mn/Na/W-calc air; 1.2m2 g−1 for SiC 56-Mn/Na/W-calc air) than that of the corresponding fresh and air-calcined supports (see Table 1). For both air-calcined catalysts, XRD analysis indicates that the original 3C-SiC phase converts into a mixture of 3C-SiC, 5H-SiC as well as crystalline SiO2 α-cristobalite. Moreover, crystalline Na2WO4, Mn2WO4 and Mn2O3 are formed (Fig. 2c), i.e. phases that were previously reported in literature for Mn/Na/W/SiO2 catalysts [18]. These metal-containing crystal phases exhibit small number of signals and relatively low intensity. Hence, calcination of Mn/Na/W/SiC in air induces a complete loss of porosity of SiC support and a structural transformation, whereas uncoated SiC supports retained their porosity and structure under the same calcination conditions (see Fig. 1). In comparison to the air-treated Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts, their N2-treated counterparts retain their fine grained morphology (Fig. 2a) and the original pore size distribution (Fig. 2b). In addition, BET analysis indicates that about 60% of the initial surface area of the support, i.e. about 15–18m2/g, are preserved (Table 1). Moreover, XRD indicates that the N2 calcined catalysts also retain the 3C-SiC of the support with negligible amounts of α-cristobalite being formed (Fig. 2c). In addition, minor amounts of SixNy, CxNy or other SiC phases appear to be formed and no metal-containing crystal phase can be apparently observed. Hence, calcination of Mn/Na/W/SiC in N2 preserves the structure and porosity of SiC much better than calcination in air. Moreover, EDX mapping analysis of Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts was performed to detect whether the Mn, Na and W element had been dispersed homogeneously over the whole catalyst structure. As shown in Fig. S4, the homogeneous distribution of Mn, Na and W element in micrometer scale is observed for Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts calcined in air and in N2. XPS were recorded in Mn2p, Na1s, W4f, W5d, O1s, Si2p and C1s region in order to determine the near-surface composition of the catalysts. The corresponding spectra are shown in Fig. S5 and the determined composition is shown in Table S6. The charging process occurred on the air-calcined sample and its element scans were corrected with −4.4eV, but this does not affect the relative amount of surface species which was calculated from the overview scan areas. XP spectrum of N2-calcined catalyst shows that in Si2p region, two distinct contributions can be assigned to SiC as well as SiO2. Both are about the same amount. The contrast air-calcined catalyst shows only one signal contribution, suggesting that SiC was scarcely retained in near-surface region. Similar observation can be made in C1s region of spectra. Also the N2-calciend catalyst shows additional signals at 282.5eV and 284.2eV, which can be assigned to Si-C and graphite carbon. However, these two peaks cannot be observed for the air-calcined catalyst. Note that the sample where subject to significant charging during XPS analysis hangs no clear assignment to different oxidation state or specific species which can be made based on binding energy alone. However, the relative amount of surface species of different metals as well as O, Si and C was calculated from the relative size of the peak areas as shown in Table S6. The N2-calcined catalyst shows higher Mn, Na and W amount on the surface compared to the bulk composition. However, for the air-calcined catalyst, Mn and W seem to disappear from the surface due to significant structure reconstruction when calcination in air. Besides, the air-calcined catalyst exhibits higher O and lower C surface amount compared to the N2-calcined catalyst, which confirms the oxidation of SiC support into SiO2 when calcination in air. TGA of SiC supports and Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts was performed in N2 as well as air in order to elucidate the origin of the calcination-induced modifications. Fig. 3 plots the TGA data obtained for materials based on SiC 56 as relative mass vs. temperature (see SI Fig. S7 for complementary data on SiC 27). The mass of uncoated support SiC 56 remains stable up to 1000°C and up to 810°C, when the support was treated in nitrogen and air respectively. The slight increase in mass can be attributed to the oxidation of SiC to SiO2, which typically forms a protective layer on the surface of SiC and prevents further oxidation of SiC [20]. Also the catalyst SiC 56-Mn/Na/W does not show a significant increase in mass when heated in N2. In contrast, it shows a dramatic increase in mass already at 450°C when heated in air, which progressively increases at higher temperatures. The progressing mass increase implies the oxidation of the support far beyond a passivating surface layer, i.e. bulk oxidation of about 50% of the SiC into SiO2. The ongoing oxidation can be attributed to the presence of metal species, and in particular sodium, which probably induces a melting of the protective SiO2 layer [25,26]. In consequence, no effective passivation layer is formed, thus the oxidation of SiC progresses further into the bulk of the material and destroys the supports original pore structure. However, the bulk oxidation and sintering of the support can be prevented by calcination in N2, which produces Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts with high surface area and porosity. 3.3 Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts after OCM The different Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts were tested in OCM up to 800°C and subsequently analyzed to reveal reaction-induced property changes. Fig. 4 displays corresponding data obtained via SEM, N2 sorption, and XRD. SEM analysis indicates that all catalysts show a sintered morphology after OCM testing (Fig. 4a). Moreover, the surface area decreases to about 1.2–1.9m2/g for all catalysts (Table 1). Hence, the initial pore structure of Mn/Na/W/SiC that was preserved in N2 atmosphere at 800°C significantly degrades in OCM feed gas (CH4/O2/N2) at 800°C. None of the catalysts can retain the supports initial pore size distribution and distinct mesoporosity under OCM conditions (Fig. 4b). Moreover, all used Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts show well-distinguished XRD reflections that can be assigned to α-cristobalite along with 3C-SiC after OCM (Fig. 4c). Other phases observed on all catalysts after OCM include Na2WO4, Mn2WO4, Mn2O3. Hence, Na promoted SiC oxidation occurs also under OCM atmosphere, producing for all tested Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts similar structure, composition and porosity independent of the initially applied calcination atmosphere. 3.4 Catalytic performance in OCM The OCM performance of Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts with different supports and different calcination procedure was tested by co-feeding CH4:O2:N2 =2:1:4 continuously to a reactor and increasing temperature in steps of 25K from 450°C to 800°C. Fig. 5 (a–d) shows for each tested catalyst the concentration of products formed at different temperatures. The catalysts that were calcined in air, i.e. SiC 27-Mn/Na/W-calc air (Fig. 5a) and SiC 56-Mn/Na/W-calc air (Fig. 5b) produce CO and CO2 starting at about 625°C. Ethane formation starts at about 650°C, followed by ethylene formation at temperatures above 675–700°C. Propane and propene form significantly between 750 and 800°C (not shown here). They are in a small quantity (C3 selectivity below 2%), which is much less than C2 product at the same temperature. For both catalysts ethylene is the main C2 product at 800°C. In general, higher product formation rates were observed for SiC 27-Mn/Na/W-calc air, i.e. that catalyst that retains a higher surface area after OCM (see Table 1). The catalysts that were calcined in N2, i.e. SiC 27-Mn/Na/W-calc N2 (Fig. 5c) and SiC 56-Mn/Na/W-calc N2 (Fig. 5d) show a different behavior during OCM catalysis below 700°C. Both catalysts form CO and CO2 already below 500°C. Formation of ethane starts at around 675°C, followed by ethylene formation. At 800°C the product spectra look similar to the air-calcined catalysts (Fig. 5a, b), with ethylene being the main C2 product. The formation of COx well below 600°C is observed only for the N2 calcined catalysts. No significant amounts methane are converted at such temperatures (Fig. 6 a) Hence, the COx is likely to originate from Na promoted bulk oxidation of SiC as observed during catalyst calcination in air (Figs. 2 and 3), and corroborated by the loss of pore structure for both N2-calcined catalysts during OCM (Fig. 4). Carbon balance for each catalyst at each temperature step was calculated and shown in Table S8. All values of nearly 100% with acceptable experimental error indicate that the analytical results are reliable. The obtained methane conversion and C2 yields are plotted vs. temperature (Fig. 6a/b). The influence of temperature on methane conversion (Fig. 6a) and C2 yield (Fig. 6b) is similar for all tested SiC-based catalysts. Methane conversion starts around 625°C, the formation of C2 product at about 650–675°C. Despite very similar trends, differences can be observed in the achieved overall activity, with catalysts based on SiC 27 converting more methane (Fig. 6a) and producing more C2 hydrocarbons (Fig. 6b) than catalysts based on SiC 56. In order to quantify the difference between the catalysts, the methane conversion (Fig. 6c) and C2 yield (Fig. 6d) obtained at 725, 750, 775 and 800°C (labeled in green, yellow, blue and red color respectively) were plotted vs. the BET surface area of the respective catalysts as measured after OCM reaction. The left box in Fig. 6c includes methane conversion of four SiC supported catalysts with different BET surface area at different temperature. It is evident that methane conversion scales linear with the amount of surface preserved during OCM, for all SiC-based catalysts. Four dash lines indicate that the linear relationship can be observed at 725, 750, 775 and 800°C. Moreover, also the yield of C2 scales roughly linear with the preserved surface area. Hence, OCM reaction appears to proceed in a very similar fashion over the four Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts that were prepared with an identical nominal composition, but differed in the initial pore structure of the employed SiC supports as well as the atmosphere applied during calcination at 800°C. The amount of surface area preserved under OCM conditions therefore appears to be the primary factor that allows high activity and C2 yields on Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts. While such a direct correlation between feed conversion and product formation with the provided surface area is expected for surface-catalyzed reactions, it is not straight-forward for reactions that comprise a complex reaction network of coupled surface- and gas-phase reaction as often proposed for OCM. The observed linear dependency thus suggests that at least for the studied catalyst system both, feed consumption as well as C2 formation rates, are controlled by the corresponding catalytic surface reactions, not subsequent or parallel reaction steps proceeding in the gas phase. In order to examine the catalyst stability, SiC 27-Mn/Na/W calcined in air and in N2 were chosen as representative to test the catalytic performance at reaction temperature of 600 and 700°C. At each temperature 5 GC test rounds (3 hours roughly) were performed. The results are shown in Fig. S9. The air-calcined catalyst exhibits stable catalytic performance. But for the N2-calcined catalyst, higher CO and CO2 product concentration was observed than the air-calcined catalyst, which is similar to the comparison between Fig. 5a and c. This is caused by SiC oxidation under OCM feed for the N2-calcined catalyst as discussed above. Besides, CO and CO2 concentration decrease with longer time at each temperature, which may be attributed to less SiC remaining in the catalyst with SiC oxidation proceeding. Therefore, the N2-calcined catalyst shows less stable catalytic performance due to the deactivation arising from SiC oxidation under OCM feed. Catalysts of similar composition were prepared for reference also on a commercial high-surface area silica support Davisil (ca. 400m2/g) using the same impregnation procedure and air-calcination at 800°C. Fig. S10 of the SI displays corresponding analysis via SEM, N2 sorption and XRD before and after OCM catalysis. Similar to SiC, the catalyst displays a sintered structure after air-calcination and after OCM catalysis, and a severe loss of surface area from more than 400m2/g to about 6.9m2/g after OCM catalysis. The presence of Na is suspected of facilitating the structural change of SiO2 [27], which induces dramatic loss of surface area. Similar to the SiC-based materials the catalyst is composed of α-cristobalite, tridymite, Na2WO4 and Mn2O3. The catalyst shows a similar influence of temperature on product formation (Fig. S10d), methane conversion (Fig. 6a) and C2 yield (Fig. 6b) as the SiC-based catalysts. Hence, the partial conversion of SiC into SiO2 during calcination and OCM catalysis produces catalysts of very similar composition, surface area and catalytic behavior as a synthesis that starts directly from silica. However, when comparing the catalytic performance based on the surface area as measured after OCM, catalysts supported on SiC show a higher methane conversion (left box in Fig. 6c) and C2 yield (left box in Fig. 6d) per m2 of surface area than supported on SiO2 (right box in Fig. 6c/d), which suggests a higher surface coverage with active sites on the SiC based materials. In further studies, SiC support for Mn/Na/W catalysts exhibits potential advantage with enhanced catalytic performance, if its surface area could approach a similar level to SiO2 support under OCM conditions. 4 Summary & conclusion Porous SiC is an efficient support material for the preparation of OCM catalysts with active Mn/Na/W-containing phases. The catalyst pore structure and high surface area could be preserved during calcination in N2, but not during calcination in air and under conditions of OCM catalysis. In contrast, uncoated SiC supports proved to be stable under similar calcination conditions. The loss of surface area and pore structure in the presence of the catalytically active elements can be attributed to the presence of sodium. Whereas pure SiC forms a passivating SiO2 layer under oxidizing conditions, Na promotes a melting of the passivation layer, which results in bulk oxidation of SiC and material sintering. Despite the sintering, Mn/Na/W-SiC catalysts show similar activities and C2 yields as silica based catalysts. Moreover, methane conversion and C2 yield scale roughly linear with the specific surface area of used catalysts, suggesting that the number of accessible active site scales with the retained surface area. OCM tests suggest that the performance of Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts depends critically on the supports stability, i.e. the surface area retained under reaction conditions. A further improvement in catalytic performance could be achieved with new concepts that provide a higher surface area of SiC-based support in the presence of Na under OCM conditions. coredata.dc:description: Efficient conversion of methane to higher hydrocarbons via oxidative coupling of methane “OCM” is one of the dream reactions in heterogeneous catalysis. Promising yields of C2 hydrocarbons were reported for nanostructured catalysts based on Mn/Na/W-SiO2. However, the exact role of the nanostructure could not be studied so far due to collapse of the pore structure of the SiO2 support at typical OCM temperatures. We investigate porous SiC as an alternative catalyst support for OCM catalysis. Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts with different pore size were synthesized via impregnation, calcined under different atmospheres and then studied in OCM. The calcination critically impacts the pore structure and surface area of the obtained catalysts. Calcination in nitrogen preserves the support’s structure significantly better than calcination in air. However, the nitrogen-calcined catalysts show a strong loss of porosity during OCM testing. The loss of porosity is caused by the presence of Na, which induces a melting of the surface layer that typically protects SiC against bulk oxidation. OCM tests suggest that the activity and C2 yield of Mn/Na/W/SiC catalysts depend critically on the supports stability, i.e. the surface area retained under reaction conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Porous silicon carbide as a support for Mn/Na/W/SiC catalyst in the oxidative coupling of methane
